./.title: Introduction and Motivation
./.body:
Introduction

Why write another React guide? Early in my development career I had a hard time learning and grasping the concepts of ASP.NET. The learning curve felt steeper than Mount Everest. In part, .NET is a large ecosystem with much to offer but I believe some of the difficulty stemmed from "beginner" tutorials that assumed too much of readers. Tutorials that took for granted templated projects and scaffolded boilerplate code. Tutorials that glossed over IDE features and did little to explain the startup process or lifecycle of a running application.
The world of JavaScript has grown into a complex one and a close friend of mine is having a hard time navigating the ever-changing landscape. Who can blame them. JavaScript use to be a collection of script tags containing nothing more than jQuery DOM manipulations located in the head or body of an html page. Now a days, large JS applications may contain hundreds of files, often involve a build process, external dependencies from various locations, and must deal with problems that stem from asynchronous programming.
JavaScript is no longer just a language but a complex ecosystem consisting of runtime environments, package managers and build tools. The language itself comes in a variety of flavors with varying support. More on that later. If that is not enough, developers may even forgo JavaScript altogether and write in a language that compiles to JavaScript. Again, more on this later.
My goal for this book is to start with nothing and to build everything. To start from a basic React example with a simple build process and, like much of development, take an iterative approach to building out a feature-filled React application with a robust build process. To slowly build a knowledge base of React, JavaScript and the surrounding ecosystem. Above all else, my goal is to not only show code but explain the reasoning of how said code came to be.

before-starting.html.title: Before Getting Started
before-starting.html.body:
Before Getting Started

Basic understanding of HTML and CSS will be assumed.

primer.html.title: Reference

getting-started/intro.html.title: Getting Started
getting-started/intro.html.body:
Getting Started

This section will walk through the process of creating a starting point from which the rest of the book will be built upon. Starting with installing the tools needed to follow along and ending with a simple Hello-World React application.

getting-started/environment.html.title: Environment
getting-started/environment.html.body:
Environment

The tool belt.

Node
Visual Studio Code
Google Chrome

Node

Install the latest LTS version of Node. Version 8.x of Node will be used for this book. 
$ node -v
# 8.x

Node comes with node package manager (npm).
npm -v
# 5.x

Visual Studio Code

Visual Studio Code. It's my code editor of choice. It's awesome. Check it out (or don't, any code editor suited for web development will work).
Google Chrome

Google Chrome, with React Developer Tools installed, will be used throughout this book for viewing and troubleshooting React code.

getting-started/project-structure.html.title: Project Structure
getting-started/project-structure.html.body:
Project Structure

Make a new project directory and add a package.json file with npm init.
# make project directory
$ mkdir react-guide

# navigate to project directory
$ cd react-guide 

# create package.json file.
$ npm init -y


Open in VSCode and create the following project structure
$ code .

react-guide/
|-- src/
    |-- app.jsx
|-- index.html
|-- package.json
|-- webpack.config.js

Index.html





    
    
    
    React Guide


    



Package.json

Add the following devDependencies and build script to package.json.
{
  "name": "react-guide",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "devDependencies": {
    "babel-core": "^6.26.0",
    "babel-loader": "^7.1.3",
    "babel-preset-env": "^1.6.1",
    "babel-preset-react": "^6.24.1",
    "react": "^16.2.0",
    "react-dom": "^16.2.0",
    "react-router-dom": "^4.2.2",
    "webpack": "^4.0.1",
    "webpack-cli": "^2.0.10"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1",
    "build": "webpack --mode development"
  },
  "keywords": [],
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC"
}

The dependencies can be grouped into three primary tools. 

React: Packages that provide React functionality and dependencies for building React applications.
Babel: The tool used to transpile ES2015 and JSX (part of React, as we will see) to the more widely supported ES5.
Webpack: The module bundler. Webpack will bundle modules and, through plugins with Babel, transpile the source code to ES5 during the bundling process. 

The scripts.build command added to package.json will allow us to run $ npm run build in the terminal which, in turn, will run webpack. 
Webpack.config.js

Covered in the next section.
